71214.desc: The politics of identity and recognition as the basis for institutional legitimacy and social struggles in the late 20th century. Conflicting views of Hegel's master-slave dialectic are used to relate, e.g., Sartre, Fanon, Bataille, Merleau-Ponty, Foucault, Lacan, Levinas, Derrida, Deleuze, Zizek, and Badiou to present-day concerns.
71214.re: Enrollment restricted to legal studies majors during priority period.

71215.desc: Explores the role of law in both enabling and constraining the actions of elected politicians in the U.S. Among issues examined are voting rights, redistricting, and campaign finance. Course asks how the law shapes and limits our ability to choose our elected leaders, and in turn, how the law is shaped by political forces.
71215.re: Enrollment restricted to legal studies majors during priority enrollment.

71216.desc: Current and future relationships between law and psychology, paying special attention to gaps between legal fictions and psychological realities in the legal system. Topics include an introduction to social science and law, the nature of legal and criminal responsibility, the relationship between the social and legal concepts of discrimination, and the nature of legal punishment.
71216.re: Psychology 3 or 100 and 40 are recommended prior to taking this course. Enrollment restricted to psychology, pre-psychology, and legal studies majors.

71217.desc: Introduces linguistics through studying the structure and culture of American Sign Language (ASL). Topics include: syntax; morphology and phonology of ASL; deaf culture; language policy; variety in signed languages; and ASL literature. No prior knowledge of ASL or linguistics required.

71218.desc: Introduction to the logical foundations of natural language semantics. Logical and semantic relations, simple set theory, logical representations (propositional and predicate calculi, modal and tense logics) and their interpretations. A basic literacy course in the language of logical representation.

71219.desc: An investigation into the various uses and abuses of "race" in 20th-century fiction. Authors may include Jean Rhys, Paul Bowles, Mark Twain, Russell Banks, Darius James, Joseph Conrad, Nella Larsen, LeRoi Jones/Amiri Baraka, Leslie Marmon Silko, and V.S. Naipaul.

71220.desc: Intensive work in writing fiction. Satisfies the Creative Writing Literature concentration. May be repeated for credit.
71220.re: Enrollment restricted to creative writing literature majors.

71221.desc: Studies in the theory of cultural studies.Course topic changes; see the Schedule of Classes for current topic. Satisfies the World Literature concentration; also satisfies the Global distribution requirement. May be repeated for credit.

71222.desc: Cell and molecular biology of bacteria and their viruses, including applications in medicine, public health, agriculture, and biotechnology.
71222.re: BIOL 100 or BIOC 100A. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71223.desc: An introduction to the principles and practices of laboratory microbiology, with a substantial presentation of optical microscopy. Students are billed a materials fee.
71223.re: previous or concurrent enrollment in course 119 is required;satisfaction of Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71224.desc: An introduction to the principles and practices of laboratory microbiology, with a substantial presentation of optical microscopy. Students are billed a materials fee.
71224.re: previous or concurrent enrollment in course 119 is required;satisfaction of Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71225.desc: A study of selected masterworks in relation to the periods which they represent. Emphasis upon the listening experience and awareness of musical style and structure. Illustrated lectures and directed listening. (Formerly

71226.desc: Designed to provide students with thorough and comprehensive background in history and roots of jazz as a musical style from its African roots to the present. Essential jazz styles and traditions are discussed through lectures, required listening, readings, lecture demonstrations, and film presentations.

71228.desc: An examination of the beginnings of analytic philosophy, with primary interest in the reformulation of traditional philosophical problems by Frege, Russell, and the early Wittgenstein. Some attention is also paid to the development of Vienna Circle logical positivism (Schlick, Carnap, Waismann). May be repeated for credit.
71228.re: course 100A or 100B or 100C. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71229.desc: Introduces the study of politics through the analysis of national political systems within or across regions from the developing world to post-industrial nations. Typical topics include: authoritarian and democratic regimes; state institutions and capacity; parties and electoral systems; public policies; social movements; ethnic conflict; and globalization.

71230.desc: Examines the relationship between state and economy in the U.S. from the 1880s to the present, and provides a theoretical and historical introduction to the study of politics and markets. Focus is on moments of crisis and choice in U.S. political economy, with an emphasis on the rise of regulation, the development of the welfare state, and changes in employment policies.
71230.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71231.desc: Introduces basic concepts in cognitive psychology. Topics include thinking, consciousness, perceiving, language, remembering, reasoning, problem solving, and decision-making.

71232.desc: An examination of contemporary theory and research on social and emotional development from infancy through childhood.
71232.re: courses 3 or 100 and 10. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71233.desc: Examines the human phenomenon of love from a psychological perspective. Through an analysis of key theoretical and empirical findings,  explores biological, cognitive, social, and personality components of love. Examines love across the lifespan and across cultures, as well as the future course of romantic relationships as evidenced by stories. Satisfies the seminar requirement. Satisfies the senior comprehensive requirement.
71233.re: course 3 or 100; satisfaction of entry-level writing and composition requirements. Enrollment restricted to senior psychology majors.

71234.desc: An examination of the physiological mechanisms of psychological processes, including sensory systems, motor systems, control systems, and memory and learning. Principles of nervous system organization are discussed at each level.
71234.re: course 3 or 100 or Biology 70 and one course in statistics (course 2 or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 5 or 7). Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71235.desc: Addresses how work is organized and shapes life changes. Covers: the history of paid work; the impact of technology; race/class/gender at work; professional and service work; work and family; collective responses to work; and challenges of work in a globalizing economy.
71235.re: Enrollment restricted to juniors and seniors.

71236.desc: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various sociopolitical and cultural issues in the Spanish speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
71236.re: course 3, 3T, 3X, or Spanish Placement Examination score of 40.

71237.desc: Students learn strategies to write, analyze, and deliver effective speeches of various kinds as well as professional presentations using PowerPoint and other visuals.
71237.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71238.desc: Students learn the classical practice of painting the nude figure from life using traditional oil painting techniques. Students study short poses, limited color, and graduate to long pose, full color. Students are billed a materials fee. May be repeated for credit.

71239.desc: Hacking is the modification, reconfiguration, and reuse of computer code and/or hardware to create new functionality. Course encourages a hands-on approach to digital-media creation while experimenting with hacking techniques. No programming experience required.

71240.desc: Introduces electronics using the open-source Arduino platform. Learn how to build interactive circuits through hands-on tutorials. In a workshop environment, students acquire the technical skills required to create electronic artwork. No previous experience required.

71241.desc: Detailed literary analysis of novels by Gogol, Goncharov, Tolstoy, Dostoevsky, and Pasternak. Focus upon aesthetic devices of texts, as well as upon ethical and philosophical issues that inform them. Satisfies the Modern and World Literature concentrations; also satisfies the Global distribution requirement.

71242.desc: An introduction to the art and craft of making films and videos. Covers principles of cinematography, videography, editing, production planning, and lighting involving both production techniques and methods. Students are billed a materials fee.  Prerequisite(s): course 20A or 20B and one other film/video and digital media critical studies or history course required. Completion of additional upper-division film and digital media critical studies or history courses improves students' ability to be admitted to this course. Admission by application and entrance essay. The online application process begins several weeks prior to the start of the quarter. See enrollment conditions section in quarterly

71243.desc: The politics of identity and recognition as the basis for institutional legitimacy and social struggles in the late 20th century. Conflicting views of Hegel's master-slave dialectic are used to relate, e.g., Sartre, Fanon, Bataille, Merleau-Ponty, Foucault, Lacan, Levinas, Derrida, Deleuze, Zizek, and Badiou to present-day concerns.
71243.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71244.desc: Explores the role of law in both enabling and constraining the actions of elected politicians in the U.S. Among issues examined are voting rights, redistricting, and campaign finance. Course asks how the law shapes and limits our ability to choose our elected leaders, and in turn, how the law is shaped by political forces.
71244.re: Enrollment restricted to politics and Latin American and Latino studies/politics combined majors during priority enrollment only.

71245.desc: Current and future relationships between law and psychology, paying special attention to gaps between legal fictions and psychological realities in the legal system. Topics include an introduction to social science and law, the nature of legal and criminal responsibility, the relationship between the social and legal concepts of discrimination, and the nature of legal punishment.
71245.re: courses 3 or 100; and course 40 is highly recommended prior to taking this course. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71246.desc: Studies of selected authors or issues in English language literature. Course topic changes; see the Schedule of Classes for current topic. Satisfies the English literature concentration; also satisfies the Senior Seminar distribution requirement.
71246.re: Literature 101. Enrollment restricted to senior Literature majors.

71247.desc: Studies in 19th- and early 20th-century theory, centering on the themes of capitalism, labor, alienation, culture, freedom, and morality. Authors studied include J. S. Mill, Marx, Nietzsche, Foucault, Hegel, Fanon, and Weber.
71247.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71248.desc: Students are given the opportunity to write their own scripts and refine them as the result of class discussion and scenework with actors. Work is on specific problems involving such elements as the structuring of a plot or the development of character. May be repeated for credit.
71248.re: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Prerequisites waived for non-UCSC students.

71249.desc: Is war inevitable? What is peace? Is it more than the absence of violence? Explore how psychology— the study of human behavior —can help to decrease violence and enhance cooperation at multiple levels including the personal, interpersonal, community, and international arenas. Satisfies seminar requirement. Satisfies senior comprehensive requirement.
71249.re: Enrollment restricted to senior psychology majors.

71250.desc: Challenges of performing Shakespearean and Renaissance plays are explored through confronting the acting problems they pose. Attention to verse scansion, character analysis, and textual meaning. Strategies for enacting scenes and monologues are tested in class presentations. May be repeated for credit.

71259.desc: Examines images of war from 1400 to present. Class discusses the many aspects of war while considering major painters of the last 600 years, including da Vinci, Rubens, Goya, Picasso. Class also discusses Callot, Marinetti, etc., and other media, including film, photography, and public monuments.

71260.desc: Examines contemporary artists who expand and complicate notions of "site." Since the 1960s, artists have used the materialities of particular places, times, and relations to challenge sociopolitical regimes and speculate about new worlds. Provides a conceptual toolkit for considering emergent site-driven practices

71261.desc: Basic studies in musicianship related to Western European notation and literature. Students with prior training in music notation develop literacy in basic tonal melody and harmony. Skills include dictation and sight-reading. Simple composition and analysis exercises accompany the training. Enrollment by placement examination and permission of instructor. May be repeated for credit.

71263.desc: Hands-on course introduces students to basic methods and practices in animation while exposing them to independent animation artists. Students explore techniques ranging from hand-drawn, frame-by-frame animation to object animation and pixilation.

71264.desc: Hands-on course surveying the thriving micro-genres in the neutral zone between games and literature. Students read, play, and author stories that couldn't exist on a printed page. Interactive fiction, algorithmic poetry, and brand-new experiments.

71265.desc: Introduction to contemporary dance theory and practice. Focus on basic dance technique, range of styles, and aesthetic points of view of historically significant contemporary dance choreographers in America and worldwide. Students are billed a materials fee. (Formerly Dance Studio I.) May be repeated for credit.

71267.desc: Covers perspectives of Eastern philosophy; specifically, Hinduism, Jainism, Buddhism, Daoism, and Confucianism. Includes views concerning the nature of ultimate reality, personal identity, morality, the afterlife, god(s), and the problem of evil.

71268.desc: Examines history of sexuality in the U.S. from the vantage point of queer communities (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and intersex (LGBTI) identities), with special attention to issues of class, gender, race, ethnicity, repression, and resistance. Primary focus on 20th-Century U.S. queer history.

71269.desc: This introductory course explores literature and culture of the first half of the 20th century. Course materials may include literary texts, films, philosophy, visual arts, and critical essays.

71270.desc: Provides an overview of educational testing.  Appropriate use and interpretation of standardized, classroom achievement and special needs assessments are examined. Issues on fair testing of diverse populations of students are discussed within each topic area.
71270.re: Enrollment restricted to juniors, seniors, or education minors.

71271.desc: Explores how male friendship is described and idealized in classical works, and how those descriptions were mimicked or altered in the Renaissance. Examines the significance of images and metaphors used to describe male friendship. Considers the implications of male friendship and how it relates to kinship systems and the state. Satisfies the Pre- and Early Modern Studies concentration; also satisfies the Pre- and Early Modern Studies distribution requirement.

71272.desc: Survey of modern poetry; includes a variety of poetic forms. Course topic changes; see the Class Search for current topic. Satisfies the Modern Literary Studies concentration; also satisfies the Poetry distribution requirement. May be repeated for credit.

71273.desc: Explores indigenous American relationships with other-than-human nature. Studies prehistoric through contemporary beliefs and practices. Emphasis on North America but may also include attention to Central or South American cultures' relationships with nature. Features films, writings, and artwork by indigenous American people.
71273.re: Entry level writing and composition requirements.

71274.desc: Examines contested approaches for defining, documenting, and addressing environmental problems. Students will understand the reproduction of environmental inequalities and how this connects to race, ethnicity, class, gender, and power in the U.S. and Latin America.

71275.desc: Introduction to disability studies focusing on intellectual and developmental disabilities. Course will: historicize understandings of mental impairment; analyze autism as diagnosis where questions about intelligence, child development, and shared experience coalesce; and rethink approaches to cognitive difference.

71276.desc: Examines the relationship between state and economy in the U.S. from the 1880s to the present, and provides a theoretical and historical introduction to the study of politics and markets. Focus is on moments of crisis and choice in U.S. political economy, with an emphasis on the rise of regulation, the development of the welfare state, and changes in employment policies.
71276.re: Enrollment restricted to legal studies majors during priority period.

71308.desc: Designed to provide students with thorough and comprehensive background in history and roots of jazz as a musical style from its African roots to the present. Essential jazz styles and traditions are discussed through lectures, required listening, readings, lecture demonstrations, and film presentations.

71361.desc: Laboratory sequence illustrating topics covered in course 171. One two-hour laboratory session per week. Students are billed a materials fee.
71361.re: courses 101/L; previous or concurrent enrollment in course 171 required.
